bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, December 7, 1917

div1.p: Kean discusses logistical issues concerning supplies, assignments, and personnel in the Ambulance Corps.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, December 7, 1917
div1.opener:
FRANCE
December 7th, 1917.
Major General W.C. Gorgas,
Surgeon General,
Washington, D.C.
My dear General:
div1.p:
There seems to be a fatality about our correspond-
ence. Your letter of September 14th was not received until November
5th, and yours of October 6th lingered by the wayside until November
24th. Your last letter of November 2d did a little better, however,
having arrived on December 4th.

In view of my experience with the volunteer sections,
I can see that you are entirely right that I should not have bothered
about trying to persuade them to come in and waste six weeks in ex-
plaining and placating these spoiled children who thought that all
should be officers, and should be put in command of the Allentown
sections at once. If I had it to do over again I would announce
that every man that wanted to enlist had to send his name in by a
certain date, then I would have had a basis on which to estimate
how many Allentown sections would be necessary to furnish the sixty-
three which General Petain's Headquarters said was all they needed.
These could have been sent over promptly and everything would have been
settled. As it is, I have not satisfied the volunteers--no human
being could do that. I have given myself infinite trouble for
nothing, and the militarization of the service has dragged along.
Birmingham has explained all these matters to you by now, so that I
feel that I am in touch with the office.

There is one thing, however, which is still a mystery,
that is, what has delayed so long the ten additional sections and the
300 unassigned men which General Pershing asked for in his cable of
September 26th, and which were promised by the War Department in
a cable on about October 3d. In your letter of October 6th, you
say, “In response to your last cable we have forwarded ten more
sections and 300 unassigned men.” These have, however, never
arrived, but are now again promised in cable 468 of December 2d.
I know that General Pershing sent a cable on the 31st of October
asking that no more sections be sent without specific authority from
him, but this should not have headed off these sections which had
been promised to be sent immediately a month before.

The additional nine sections were a great help to me
because it has enabled me to have a few additional officers. The
provision made by the General Staff of only one lieutenant for each
section allowed no additional officers to take place of those sick,
on leave, under arrest, or in any way unavailable. As each section
has to be mustered by an officer for pay, the commutation of ration
vouchers have to be signed by an officer, and only an officer can
act as Summary Court, the conditions were impossible until
we got this leaway. All new appointments for vacancies will
now be made by promotion from the sections, and will be selected by
a board composed of field officers of the service on duty in
France. I am also going to require all candidates to go through a
Dec 7
(p.3.--Major General W.C. Gorgas)
six weeks' course in the French school at Meaux, where they give
admirable instruction in the principles of automobile structure,
the management of convois, the rules of the road and the adminis-
tration of military discipline. This course is also very valuable
in enabling us to size up a man, and get the measure of his capacity
and adaptability. We will gradually replace the medical officers,
as Bradley wants them, except a few of the younger ones who like the
service and show special qualifications for it.

I am trying now to establish a suitable Base Camp, so
that when you send over additional sections we that we can exchange
between those of the camp and those at the front so as to have some
trained sections available for our army, if needed. The French
authorities have agreed to this.

I am sending you a copy of the order showing the organi-
zation of the Headquarters' Office. The only thing with which we
are now having difficulty is the matter of spare parts. It seems
that the supply of spare parts sent over with the ambulances has
been inadequate, and as you know we are now suffering from a shortage.
Major A. P. Andrew is in charge of this division of the office, and
is handling the matter with some pessimism of spirt but with
a good deal of energy. He will, I am sure, get it straightened out.

There has been a decided tendency at the Headquarters to
criticize your office for sending over so many ambulances in excess
Dec 7
(p.4--Major General W.C. Gorgas)
of what were needed at the time. I have pointed out on all occassions
with a good deal of emphasis that the excess of transportation was
only due to the fact that the bringing over of the sections was
certainlysuddenly checked by General Pershing in consequence of the difference
of opinion of the Service de Sante and the Automobile Transport
Service as to how many sections they needed. Meanwhile, some de-
partments of the army were almost destitute of transportation, and
I have had to come to the rescue by letting them have some of the
vehicles, which for the time being we did not need. The number of
cars transferred is as follows:

Quartermaster Department.....200
Medical Department...........277
Signal Corps..................70
Engineer Corps...............100

Steps should be taken to replace these cars, which we will need by
next June, the Medical Department being re-imbrused for their cost
by transfers on the books of the Treasury. In this way we will get
cars which have not been subject to deterioration from exposure
to the weather, and we will have an opportunity to correct certain
defects in the construction of these ambulances which have developed,
as for instance, a slight enlargement of the bodies in all directions.

The Service de Sante is very anxious to have a program
approved by which fifteen sections a month will be brought over here
until the whole 120 have arrived, beginning next January. They have no
Dec 7
(p. 5--Major General Gorgas)
power to compel the Department of Munitions to assign these sections
to duty at the front, and have, I think, no very clear idea as to
what will be done with them, except that they propose to distribute
the sections around to the hospitals of the interior, a work which I
think belongs rather to the Red Cross than to the Ambulance Service.
I am quite willing to have my command increased, but I can not recommend
to General Pershing to have additional sections brought over in
addition to the twenty-seven promised before the end of the year,
without a clear and definite statement as to the need for them. This
I can not give until the Motor Service agrees to assign them to duty
at the front unless you are willing to have them stationed at the
Base Camp and alternate with the sections at the front for the purpose
of training.

Meanwhile, the difficulties of taking care of the
men properly over here are great. We have not yet been able to draw
any clothing for our men, and it is difficult to get them properly
housed. I feel very strongly that it is a mistake not to allow men
to bring over their cots, and hope that you will be able to get this
privilege for the sections coming over hereafter. Gold
Medal Cota take up very small space and in the Ambulance Service they
are absolutely necessary.

I appreciate very much the support which you have given
me, and the prompt response which you have made to my requests. I hope
Dec 7
(p. 6--Major General Gorgas)
that Birmingham will be able to inform you fully as to the difficulties
under which I have labored and the extraordinary degree to which we
are out off from a knowledge of what is going on in Washington. I haven't
received a War Department order since my arrival here, or any communi-
cations from the office, except your very welcome and informing letters.

Please, after reading this letter, turn it over to Major
Wrightson, and ask him to write to me occasionly.

With cordial greetings and best wishes for the New Year,
I am,
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J R KEAN
Colonel, Medical Corps, USA. JRK:p
